statement:
Let $X$ be a set and $\operatorname{Bou}(X,\mathbb{R})$ be the set of
bounded functions $f:X\to\mathbb{R}$ with norm
$||f||=\operatorname{sup}\{|f(x)|:\;x\in X\}$. Kuratowski’s embedding
theorem states that every metric space $(X,d)$ can be embedded
isometrically into the Banach space
$E=\operatorname{Bou}(X,\,\mathbb{R})$.

[*Proof.*]{} One can assume that $X\ne \emptyset$. Fix a point
$a_0\in X$ and for every $a\in X$ define a function $f_a:X\to\mathbb{R}$
by $$f_a(x)=d(x,a)-d(x,a_0).$$ Then $|f_a(x)|\leq d(a,a_0)$ for every
$x\in X$ so $f_a$ is bounded. By setting $\varphi :X\to E$,
$\varphi (a)=f_a$, we have the mapping $\varphi : X\to E$. It requires
to prove that $\varphi$ is an isometry.

Let $a,\,b\in X$. As $x\in X$ we have that
$$|f_a(x)-f_b(x)|=|d(x,a)-d(x,b)|\leq d(a,b).$$ Therefore
$||f_a-f_b||\leq d(a,b)$. On the other hand
$$|f_a(a)-f_b(a)|=|d(a,a)-d(a,a_0)-d(a,b)+d(a,a_0)|=d(a,b).$$ Therefore
$||\varphi (a)-\varphi (b)||=||f_a-f_b||=d(a,b)$.

951-745-209-8
